Background.text:
Has
anticholinergic
, sodium-channel blockade, anti-NMDA and antiepileptic effects
Therapeutic concentration: 4-12 mg/L

Clinical_Features.text:
May be delayed and follow crescendo-decrescendo course (due to delayed GI motility)
Neurologic
Ataxia
Nystagmus
Seizures
Coma
Anticholinergic Toxicity
Cardiovascular
Dysrhythmias are rare but may occur
Wide QRS
from sodium channel blockade
[1]
QT Prolongation

Evaluation.text: Levels do not accurately correlate with clinical severity

Management.text:
GI decontamination
Activated Charcoal
(if presents within 1hr of ingestion)
Consider
Multidose activated charcoal
Dialysis
for severe cases. Indications:
[2]
Intractable seizures or life threatening dysrhythmia (level 1D recommendation)
Respiratory depression requiring mechanical ventilation or prolonged coma (level 2D suggestion)
Significant toxicity or rising/persistent carbamazepine level despite
activated charcoal
and supportive care (level 2D suggestion)

Disposition.text: Consider discharge for patient with decreasing levels (measured few hrs apart) and is asymptomatic
